articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) has secured a new general meeting location at DeAnza College, requiring club volunteers to staff telescopes for public viewing. The article also addresses resolutions for past issues with star parties at Sanborn Canyon Park and provides updates on the Space Shuttle Columbia's modifications and launch schedule. Furthermore, it details an upcoming meeting featuring the Viking Fund's efforts to keep the Viking Lander operating on Mars, announces a new telescope making class, and mentions astronomical T-shirts.

articles.title: Occultation Results (as of October 17, 1980)
articles.summary: This report details several occultation and lunar graze events observed by SJAA members and collaborators in late 1980. Key findings include the discovery of a potential moon or debris cloud around asteroid (213) Kleopatra, and observations of a graze of ZC1420 suggesting it is a new double star. Other events included an unsuccessful attempt to observe (78) Diana and a successful graze of ZC2399, which highlighted issues with lunar limb data.

articles.title: Coming Attractions
articles.summary: This document, titled "Coming Attractions," details upcoming asteroid occultation events for amateur astronomers in November 1980, emphasizing the need for graze equipment and readiness for short-notice observations. It highlights three specific events: (94) Aurora on November 2nd, (213) Kleopatra on November 6th, and (134) Sophrosyne on November 24th, with notes on their visibility, magnitude, and potential shifts. Observers are encouraged to prepare and contact Jim Van Nuland for more information.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: As November begins, this article discusses recent professional comet recovery and discovery events, alongside three periodic comets currently visible in the morning sky. It serves as the last opportunity to view these celestial visitors, brighter than magnitude 10, before two move south for the winter. The piece also briefly recalls the previously un-discovered Comet 1979L from the prior year and provides specific updates on Periodic Comets Reinmuth 2 (1980n) and Russell 2 (1980o).

articles.title: P/Comet Stephen-Oterma (1980g)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for P/Comet Stephen-Oterma (1980g), listing its Right Ascension, Declination, and magnitude from October 18 to December 7. It also includes an observer's report describing the comet as magnitude 9.7, condensed, and 3 arcminutes across. The comet's path is noted as moving north through Orion and into Taurus, with a close approach to M1 (the Crab Nebula) in early December.

articles.title: P/Comet Tuttle (1980h)
articles.summary: This document provides an observation report for P/Comet Tuttle (1980h), including a table of its predicted positions and magnitudes from October to December 1980. The comet was personally observed at magnitude 8.9, showing condensation and a 4' diameter. Its trajectory involved moving through Ursa Major and Leo before diving south and becoming unobservable in early December.

articles.title: P/Comet Encke
articles.summary: The article provides observing data, an ephemeris, and tips for P/Comet Encke, noting its diffuse appearance and challenging nature. It then transitions to a reflection on amateur comet discoverers, discussing their motivations beyond mere fame, and expresses concern about the future of ground-based comet hunting in an era of advanced space-based observation. The author, Don Machholz, an experienced comet hunter, promises future advice on reporting discoveries.

articles.title: The Great Henry Coe Close-in Cloud Party
articles.summary: The SJAA's ten-member subcommittee, joined by guests, gathered at Henry Coe State Park for an observing event that was quickly marred by heavy cloud cover and several humorous mishaps, including a car breakdown and members getting lost. Despite discussing alternative observation methods for cloudy conditions, the consensus was to leave early if the clouds persisted, with many departing by 9 p.m. due to the lack of clear skies and distant lightning.

articles.title: Stellar Manners; or How to Behave in a Red Light District
articles.summary: This article provides a comprehensive guide to proper etiquette at star parties, emphasizing the importance of consideration for fellow astronomers to ensure a pleasant experience for all. It covers specific behaviors related to arrival, parking, equipment setup, lighting, and noise, offering practical advice to maintain dark adaptation and minimize disturbances. Adhering to these 'stellar manners' is crucial for successful observing and astrophotography sessions.

articles.title: Membership list additions:
articles.summary: This document provides an update to a membership list, detailing new members, a bulletin subscriber, changes to existing member information such as new addresses and phone numbers, and general additions. It lists individuals and couples along with their contact details, current as of December 20th.

articles.title: MAP OF AREA:
articles.summary: This document is a sketch map providing the relative locations of various areas, including Quinault, Queets, Hoh River, Forks, and Olympic National Park boundaries. It explicitly states it is not a detailed road map, showing approximate distances and indicating unimproved roads or trails, primarily for geographical context rather than precise navigation.

articles.title: WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE:
articles.summary: This document details wheelchair-accessible features available at a location, including restrooms, elevators, telephones, and automatic doors. It also provides a legend for various parking types, such as restricted, motorcycle, and dedicated wheelchair parking, and indicates the 'North' direction.

articles.title: STREET MAP
articles.summary: This document is a simplified, hand-drawn street map sketch designed to guide users to a specific "MEETING SITE." It features key local roads such as Stevens Creek Blvd, Steele Rd, and McClellan Rd, and references major routes like HWY 17 and 280, along with a mention of De Anza. The map explicitly states it is "DEFINITELY NOT TO SCALE!"
